name: repertoire
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
all the music or plays, etc. that you can do or perform or that you know: in someone’s repertoire The Royal Shakespeare Company also have many modern plays in their repertoire. There is an extensive repertoire of music written for the flute. Compare
repertory
all the things that someone can do, all the methods that someone can use, etc.: I'm not a great cook - pasta and pesto is the extent of my repertoire. As young people move from childhood into adolescence, their coping repertoires increase.
More examplesFewer examplesShe entertained with her varied repertoire of patriotic songs.The company offered a season of restaged plays from its repertoire.This is only one in a full repertoire of facial expressions.The aim is to add Standard English to the repertoire, not to replace other dialects or languages.

Skill, talent and ability
Add to word list
Add to word list
all the music, plays, dances, operas, etc., that a person or a group can perform, or that exist in a particular type of activity related to the arts: Americans don’t know the American repertoire, aside from Gershwin.
